The main functions treated in this chapter are the eigenvalues \lambda^{m}_{n}\left(\gamma^{2}\right) and the spheroidal wave functions \mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(x,\gamma^{2}\right) , \mathsf{Qs}^{m}_{n}\left(x,\gamma^{2}\right) , \mathit{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(z,\gamma^{2}\right) , \mathit{Qs}^{m}_{n}\left(z,\gamma^{2}\right) , and S^{m(j)}_{n}\left(z,\gamma\right) , j=1,2,3,4.
These notations are similar to those used in ( ) and ( ) .
( ) use \mathrm{ps} , \mathrm{qs} , \mathrm{Ps} , \mathrm{Qs} for \mathsf{Ps} , \mathsf{Qs} , \mathit{Ps} , \mathit{Qs} , respectively.

( ) and ( ) use \lambda_{mn}(\gamma) for \lambda^{m}_{n}\left(\gamma^{2}\right)+\gamma^{2} , R_{mn}^{(j)}(\gamma,z) for S^{m(j)}_{n}\left(z,\gamma\right) , and S^{(1)}_{mn}(\gamma,x)=d_{mn}(\gamma)\mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(x,\gamma^{2} \right), S^{(2)}_{mn}(\gamma,x)=d_{mn}(\gamma)\mathsf{Qs}^{m}_{n}\left(x,\gamma^{2} \right), where d_{mn}(\gamma) is a normalization constant determined by S^{(1)}_{mn}(\gamma,0)=(-1)^{m}\mathsf{P}^{m}_{n}\left(0\right), \left.\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}S^{(1)}_{mn}(\gamma,x)\right|_{x=0}=(-1)^{ m}\left.\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\mathsf{P}^{m}_{n}\left(x\right)\right|_ {x=0}, For older notations see ( , §21.11) and ( , pp. 14,15) .
\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}\left((1-z^{2})\frac{\mathrm{d}w}{\mathrm{d}z} \right)+\left(\lambda+\gamma^{2}(1-z^{2})-\frac{\mu^{2}}{1-z^{2}}\right)w=0.
This equation has regular singularities at z=\pm 1 with exponents \pm\frac{1}{2}\mu and an irregular singularity of rank 1 at z=\infty (if \gamma\neq 0 ).
The equation contains three real parameters \lambda , \gamma^{2} , and \mu.

In applications involving prolate spheroidal coordinates \gamma^{2} is positive, in applications involving oblate spheroidal coordinates \gamma^{2} is negative; see §§LABEL:sec:SW.PR, LABEL:sec:SW.OB.

The Liouville normal form of equation (LABEL:eq:SW.DE.DE) is \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}g}{{\mathrm{d}t}^{2}}+\left(\lambda+\frac{1}{4}+\gamma^{ 2}{\sin^{2}}t-\frac{\mu^{2}-\frac{1}{4}}{{\sin^{2}}t}\right)g=0, z=\cos t, w(z)=(1-z^{2})^{-\frac{1}{4}}g(t).

With \zeta=\gamma z Equation (LABEL:eq:SW.DE.DE) changes to (\zeta^{2}-\gamma^{2})\frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}\zeta}^{2}}+2\zeta \frac{\mathrm{d}w}{\mathrm{d}\zeta}+\left(\zeta^{2}-\lambda-\gamma^{2}-\frac{ \gamma^{2}\mu^{2}}{\zeta^{2}-\gamma^{2}}\right)w=0.
If \gamma=0 , Equation (LABEL:eq:SW.DE.DE) is the associated Legendre differential equation; see (LABEL:eq:LE.DE.AssocLegEq).
If \mu^{2}=\frac{1}{4} , Equation (LABEL:eq:SW.DE.NF) reduces to the Mathieu equation; see (LABEL:eq:MA.DE.Ma).
If \gamma=0 , Equation (LABEL:eq:SW.DE.DE3) is satisfied by spherical Bessel functions; see (LABEL:eq:BS.DBP.DE.1).

With \mu=m=0,1,2,\dots , the spheroidal wave functions \mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(x,\gamma^{2}\right) are solutions of Equation (LABEL:eq:SW.DE.DE) which are bounded on (-1,1) , or equivalently, which are of the form (1-x^{2})^{\frac{1}{2}m}g(x) where g(z) is an entire function of z.
These solutions exist only for eigenvalues \lambda^{m}_{n}\left(\gamma^{2}\right) , n=m,m+1,m+2,\dots , of the parameter \lambda.

The eigenvalues \lambda^{m}_{n}\left(\gamma^{2}\right) are analytic functions of the real variable \gamma^{2} and satisfy \lambda^{m}_{m}\left(\gamma^{2}\right)<\lambda^{m}_{m+1}\left(\gamma^{2}\right )<\lambda^{m}_{m+2}\left(\gamma^{2}\right)<\cdots, \lambda^{m}_{n}\left(\gamma^{2}\right)=n(n+1)-\tfrac{1}{2}\gamma^{2}+O\left(n^ {-2}\right), subject to n\to\infty, \lambda^{m}_{n}\left(0\right)=n(n+1), -1<\frac{\mathrm{d}\lambda^{m}_{n}\left(\gamma^{2}\right)}{\mathrm{d}(\gamma^{ 2})}<0.

If p is an even nonnegative integer, then the continued-fraction equation \beta_{p}-\lambda-\cfrac{\alpha_{p-2}\gamma_{p}}{\beta_{p-2}-\lambda-\cfrac{ \alpha_{p-4}\gamma_{p-2}}{\beta_{p-4}-\lambda-\cdots}}=\cfrac{\alpha_{p}\gamma _{p+2}}{\beta_{p+2}-\lambda-\cfrac{\alpha_{p+2}\gamma_{p+4}}{\beta_{p+4}- \lambda-\cdots}}, where \alpha_{k} , \beta_{k} , \gamma_{k} are defined by \alpha_{k}=-(k+1)(k+2), \beta_{k}=(m+k)(m+k+1)-\gamma^{2}, \gamma_{k}=\gamma^{2}, has the solutions \lambda=\lambda^{m}_{m+2j}\left(\gamma^{2}\right) , j=0,1,2,\dots.
If p is an odd positive integer, then Equation (LABEL:eq:SW.EV.CF) has the solutions \lambda=\lambda^{m}_{m+2j+1}\left(\gamma^{2}\right) , j=0,1,2,\dots.
If p=0 or p=1 , the finite continued-fraction on the left-hand side of (LABEL:eq:SW.EV.CF) equals 0; if p>1 its last denominator is \beta_{0}-\lambda or \beta_{1}-\lambda.

In equation (LABEL:eq:SW.EV.CF) we can also use \alpha_{k}=\gamma^{2}\frac{(k+2m+1)(k+2m+2)}{(2k+2m+3)(2k+2m+5)}, \beta_{k}=(k+m)(k+m+1)-2\gamma^{2}\frac{(k+m)(k+m+1)-1+m^{2}}{(2k+2m-1)(2k+2m+ 3)}, \gamma_{k}=\gamma^{2}\frac{(k-1)k}{(2k+2m-3)(2k+2m-1)}.
For values of r_{n}^{m} see ( , p. 109) .
Further coefficients can be found with the Maple program SWF9; see §LABEL:sec:SW.SO.IS.
The eigenfunctions of (LABEL:eq:SW.DE.DE) that correspond to the eigenvalues \lambda^{m}_{n}\left(\gamma^{2}\right) are denoted by \mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(x,\gamma^{2}\right) , n=m,m+1,m+2,\dots.

They are normalized by the condition \int_{-1}^{1}\left(\mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(x,\gamma^{2}\right)\right)^{2} \mathrm{d}x=\frac{2}{2n+1}\frac{(n+m)!}{(n-m)!} , the sign of \mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(0,\gamma^{2}\right) being (-1)^{(n+m)/2} when n-m is even, and the sign of \ifrac{\mathrm{d}\mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(x,\gamma^{2}\right)}{\mathrm{d}x}|_{ x=0} being (-1)^{(n+m-1)/2} when n-m is odd.

When \gamma^{2}>0 \mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(x,\gamma^{2}\right) is theprolate angular spheroidal wave function, and when \gamma^{2}<0 \mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(x,\gamma^{2}\right) is theoblate angular spheroidal wave function.

If \gamma=0 , \mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(x,0\right) reduces to the Ferrers function \mathsf{P}^{m}_{n}\left(x\right) : \mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(x,0\right)=\mathsf{P}^{m}_{n}\left(x\right); compare §LABEL:sec:LE.DHR.D1.
\mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(-x,\gamma^{2}\right)=(-1)^{n-m}\mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n} \left(x,\gamma^{2}\right).
\mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(x,\gamma^{2}\right) has exactly n-m zeros in the interval -1<x<1.

\mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(x,\gamma^{2}\right)=(1-x^{2})^{\frac{1}{2}m}\sum_{k=0 }^{\infty}g_{k}x^{k}, subject to -1\leq x\leq 1, where \alpha_{k}g_{k+2}+(\beta_{k}-\lambda^{m}_{n}\left(\gamma^{2}\right))g_{k}+ \gamma_{k}g_{k-2}=0 with \alpha_{k} , \beta_{k} , \gamma_{k} from (LABEL:eq:SW.SW.AL), and g_{-1}=g_{-2}=0 , g_{k}=0 for even k if n-m is odd and g_{k}=0 for odd k if n-m is even.
Normalization of the coefficients g_{k} is effected by application of (LABEL:eq:SW.SW.NO).
\int_{-1}^{1}\mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{k}\left(x,\gamma^{2}\right)\mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n} \left(x,\gamma^{2}\right)\mathrm{d}x=\frac{2}{2n+1}\frac{(n+m)!}{(n-m)!}\delta _{k,n}.

If f(x) is mean-square integrable on [-1,1] , then formally f(x)=\sum_{n=m}^{\infty}c_{n}\mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(x,\gamma^{2}\right), where c_{n}=(n+\tfrac{1}{2})\frac{(n-m)!}{(n+m)!}\int_{-1}^{1}f(t)\mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n }\left(t,\gamma^{2}\right)\mathrm{d}t.

The expansion (LABEL:eq:SW.SW.EX) converges in the norm of L^{2}(-1,1) , that is, \lim_{N\to\infty}\int_{-1}^{1}{\left|f(x)-\sum_{n=m}^{N}c_{n}\mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{ n}\left(x,\gamma^{2}\right)\right|^{2}}\mathrm{d}x=0.
It is also equiconvergent with its expansion in Ferrers functions (as in (LABEL:eq:SW.SW.NO2)), that is, the difference of corresponding partial sums converges to 0 uniformly for -1\leq x\leq 1.
Other solutions of (LABEL:eq:SW.DE.DE) with \mu=m , \lambda=\lambda^{m}_{n}\left(\gamma^{2}\right) , and z=x are \mathsf{Qs}^{m}_{n}\left(x,\gamma^{2}\right), subject to n=m,m+1,m+2,\dots.

They satisfy \mathsf{Qs}^{m}_{n}\left(-x,\gamma^{2}\right)=(-1)^{n-m+1}\mathsf{Qs}^{m}_{n} \left(x,\gamma^{2}\right), and \mathsf{Qs}^{m}_{n}\left(x,0\right)=\mathsf{Q}^{m}_{n}\left(x\right); compare §LABEL:sec:LE.DHR.D1.

Also, \mathscr{W}\left\{\mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(x,\gamma^{2}\right),\mathsf{Qs}^{m} _{n}\left(x,\gamma^{2}\right)\right\}=\frac{(n+m)!}{(1-x^{2})(n-m)!}A_{n}^{m}( \gamma^{2})A_{n}^{-m}(\gamma^{2})\quad(\neq 0), with A_{n}^{\pm m}(\gamma^{2}) as in (LABEL:eq:SW.SJ.DA).
For further properties see ( ) and §LABEL:sec:SW.LF.SK.

The solutions \mathit{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(z,\gamma^{2}\right), \mathit{Qs}^{m}_{n}\left(z,\gamma^{2}\right), of (LABEL:eq:SW.DE.DE) with \mu=m and \lambda=\lambda^{m}_{n}\left(\gamma^{2}\right) are real when z\in(1,\infty) , and their principal values (§LABEL:sec:EF.FN.LOG) are obtained by analytic continuation to \mathbb{C}\setminus(-\infty,1].
\mathit{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(z,0\right)=P^{m}_{n}\left(z\right), \mathit{Qs}^{m}_{n}\left(z,0\right)=Q^{m}_{n}\left(z\right); compare §LABEL:sec:LE.DHR.D2.

\mathscr{W}\left\{\mathit{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(z,\gamma^{2}\right),\mathit{Qs}^{m} _{n}\left(z,\gamma^{2}\right)\right\}=\frac{(-1)^{m}(n+m)!}{(1-z^{2})(n-m)!}A_ {n}^{m}(\gamma^{2})A_{n}^{-m}(\gamma^{2}), with A_{n}^{\pm m}(\gamma^{2}) as in (LABEL:eq:SW.SJ.DA).

\mathit{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(x\pm\mathrm{i}0,\gamma^{2}\right)=(\mp\mathrm{i})^{m} \mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(x,\gamma^{2}\right), , \mathit{Qs}^{m}_{n}\left(x\pm\mathrm{i}0,\gamma^{2}\right)={(\mp\mathrm{i})^{m }\left(\mathsf{Qs}^{m}_{n}\left(x,\gamma^{2}\right)\mp\tfrac{1}{2}\mathrm{i} \pi\mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(x,\gamma^{2}\right)\right)}.
For further properties see ( ) .
For results for Equation (LABEL:eq:SW.DE.DE) with complex parameters see ( ) .

section.title: Expansions in Series of Ferrers Functions

para.sentence: \mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(x,\gamma^{2}\right)=\sum_{k=-R}^{\infty}(-1)^{k}a^{m} _{n,k}(\gamma^{2})\mathsf{P}^{m}_{n+2k}\left(x\right), where \mathsf{P}^{m}_{n+2k}\left(x\right) is the Ferrers function of the first kind (§LABEL:sec:LE.DHR.D1), R=\left\lfloor\frac{1}{2}(n-m)\right\rfloor , and the coefficients a^{m}_{n,k}(\gamma^{2}) are given by a^{m}_{n,k}(\gamma^{2})=(-1)^{k}\left(n+2k+\tfrac{1}{2}\right)\frac{(n-m+2k)!} {(n+m+2k)!}\*\int_{-1}^{1}\mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(x,\gamma^{2}\right)\mathsf{ P}^{m}_{n+2k}\left(x\right)\mathrm{d}x.

Then the set of coefficients a^{m}_{n,k}(\gamma^{2}) , k=-R,-R+1,-R+2,\dots is the solution of the difference equation A_{k}f_{k-1}+\left(B_{k}-\lambda^{m}_{n}\left(\gamma^{2}\right)\right)f_{k}+C_ {k}f_{k+1}=0, (note that A_{-R}=0 ) that satisfies the normalizing condition \sum_{k=-R}^{\infty}a_{n,k}^{m}(\gamma^{2})a_{n,k}^{-m}(\gamma^{2})\frac{1}{2n +4k+1}=\frac{1}{2n+1}, with a_{n,k}^{-m}(\gamma^{2})=\frac{(n-m)!(n+m+2k)!}{(n+m)!(n-m+2k)!}a_{n,k}^{m}( \gamma^{2}).

Also, as k\to\infty , \frac{k^{2}a^{m}_{n,k}(\gamma^{2})}{a^{m}_{n,k-1}(\gamma^{2})}=\frac{\gamma^{2 }}{16}+O\left(\frac{1}{k}\right), and \frac{\lambda^{m}_{n}\left(\gamma^{2}\right)-B_{k}}{A_{k}}\frac{a^{m}_{n,k}( \gamma^{2})}{a^{m}_{n,k-1}(\gamma^{2})}=1+O\left(\frac{1}{k^{4}}\right).

\mathsf{Qs}^{m}_{n}\left(x,\gamma^{2}\right)=\sum_{k=-\infty}^{-N-1}(-1)^{k}{a ^{\prime}}^{m}_{n,k}(\gamma^{2})\mathsf{P}^{m}_{n+2k}\left(x\right)+\sum_{k=-N }^{\infty}(-1)^{k}a^{m}_{n,k}(\gamma^{2})\mathsf{Q}^{m}_{n+2k}\left(x\right), where \mathsf{P}^{m}_{n} and \mathsf{Q}^{m}_{n} are again the Ferrers functions and N=\left\lfloor\frac{1}{2}(n+m)\right\rfloor.
The coefficients a^{m}_{n,k}(\gamma^{2}) satisfy (LABEL:eq:SW.LF.REC2) for all k when we set a^{m}_{n,k}(\gamma^{2})=0 for k<-N.
For k\geq-R they agree with the coefficients defined in §LABEL:sec:SW.LF.FK.
For k=-N,-N+1,\dots,-R-1 they are determined from (LABEL:eq:SW.LF.REC2) by forward recursion using a^{m}_{n,-N-1}(\gamma^{2})=0.

The set of coefficients {a^{\prime}}^{m}_{n,k}(\gamma^{2}) , k=-N-1,-N-2,\dots , is the recessive solution of (LABEL:eq:SW.LF.REC2) as k\to-\infty that is normalized by A_{-N-1}{a^{\prime}}^{m}_{n,-N-2}(\gamma^{2})+{\left(B_{-N-1}-\lambda^{m}_{n} \left(\gamma^{2}\right)\right){a^{\prime}}^{m}_{n,-N-1}(\gamma^{2})}+C^{\prime }a^{m}_{n,-N}(\gamma^{2})=0, with C^{\prime}=\begin{cases}\dfrac{\gamma^{2}}{4m^{2}-1},&\mbox{$n-m$ even},\\ -\dfrac{\gamma^{2}}{(2m-1)(2m-3)},&\mbox{$n-m$ odd}.\end{cases } It should be noted that if the forward recursion (LABEL:eq:SW.LF.REC2) beginning with f_{-N-1}=0 , f_{-N}=1 leads to f_{-R}=0 , then a^{m}_{n,k}(\gamma^{2}) is undefined for n<-R and \mathsf{Qs}^{m}_{n}\left(x,\gamma^{2}\right) does not exist.
Further coefficients can be found with the Maple program SWF7; see §LABEL:sec:SW.SO.IS.
For the eigenfunctions see ( , §3.251) and ( ) .
For uniform asymptotic expansions in terms of Airy or Bessel functions for real values of the parameters, complex values of the variable, and with explicit error bounds see ( ) .
See also ( ) .
Further coefficients can be found with the Maple program SWF8; see §LABEL:sec:SW.SO.IS.
For the eigenfunctions see ( , §3.252) and ( ) .
For uniform asymptotic expansions in terms of elementary, Airy, or Bessel functions for real values of the parameters, complex values of the variable,and with explicit error bounds see ( ) .
See also ( ) .
The asymptotic behavior of \lambda^{m}_{n}\left(\gamma^{2}\right) and a^{m}_{n,k}(\gamma^{2}) as n\to\infty in descending powers of 2n+1 is derived in ( ) .
The cases of large m , and of large m and large |\gamma| , are studied in ( ) .
The asymptotic behavior of \mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(x,\gamma^{2}\right) and \mathsf{Qs}^{m}_{n}\left(x,\gamma^{2}\right) as x\to\pm 1 is given in ( , p. 151) .
The behavior of \lambda^{m}_{n}\left(\gamma^{2}\right) for complex \gamma^{2} and large |\lambda^{m}_{n}\left(\gamma^{2}\right)| is investigated in ( ) .
Integrals and integral equations for \mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(x,\gamma^{2}\right) are given in ( , §8.6) , ( , §16.13) , ( , Chapter 5) , and ( ) .
For product formulas and convolutions see ( ) .
For an addition theorem, see ( , p. 300) and ( ) .
For expansions in products of spherical Bessel functions, see ( , Chapter 6) .
Here a^{-m}_{n,k}(\gamma^{2}) is defined by (LABEL:eq:SW.LF.AR) and (LABEL:eq:SW.LF.NN), and A_{n}^{\pm m}(\gamma^{2})=\sum_{2k\geq\mp m-n}(-1)^{k}a^{\pm m}_{n,k}(\gamma^{ 2})\quad(\neq 0).
In (LABEL:eq:SW.SJ.DF) z\neq 0 when j=1 , and |z|>1 when j=2,3,4.

S^{m(3)}_{n}\left(z,\gamma\right)=S^{m(1)}_{n}\left(z,\gamma\right)+\mathrm{i} S^{m(2)}_{n}\left(z,\gamma\right), S^{m(4)}_{n}\left(z,\gamma\right)=S^{m(1)}_{n}\left(z,\gamma\right)-\mathrm{i} S^{m(2)}_{n}\left(z,\gamma\right).

For fixed \gamma , as z\to\infty in the sector |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\pi-\delta ( <\pi ), S^{m(j)}_{n}\left(z,\gamma\right)=\begin{cases}\psi_{n}^{(j)}(\gamma z)+O\left (z^{-2}e^{|\Im z|}\right),&j=1,2,\\ \psi_{n}^{(j)}(\gamma z)\left(1+O\left(z^{-1}\right)\right),&j=3,4.\end{cases }
For asymptotic expansions in negative powers of z see ( , p. 293) .
\mathscr{W}\left\{S^{m(1)}_{n}\left(z,\gamma\right),S^{m(2)}_{n}\left(z,\gamma \right)\right\}=\frac{1}{\gamma(z^{2}-1)}.

S^{m(1)}_{n}\left(z,\gamma\right)=K_{n}^{m}(\gamma)\mathit{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(z, \gamma^{2}\right), S^{m(2)}_{n}\left(z,\gamma\right)=\frac{(n-m)!}{(n+m)!}\frac{(-1)^{m+1}\mathit {Qs}^{m}_{n}\left(z,\gamma^{2}\right)}{\gamma K_{n}^{m}(\gamma)A_{n}^{m}( \gamma^{2})A_{n}^{-m}(\gamma^{2})}, where K_{n}^{m}(\gamma)=\frac{\sqrt{\pi}}{2}\left(\frac{\gamma}{2}\right)^{m}\frac{( -1)^{m}a_{n,\frac{1}{2}(m-n)}^{-m}(\gamma^{2})}{\Gamma\left(\frac{3}{2}+m \right)A_{n}^{-m}(\gamma^{2})\mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(0,\gamma^{2}\right)}, subject to n-m even, or K_{n}^{m}(\gamma)=\frac{\sqrt{\pi}}{2}\left(\frac{\gamma}{2}\right)^{m+1}\* \frac{(-1)^{m}a_{n,\frac{1}{2}(m-n+1)}^{-m}(\gamma^{2})}{\Gamma\left(\frac{5}{ 2}+m\right)A_{n}^{-m}(\gamma^{2})(\left.\ifrac{\mathrm{d}\mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n}(z ,\gamma^{2})}{\mathrm{d}z}\right|_{z=0})}, subject to n-m odd.

When z\in\mathbb{C}\setminus(-\infty,1] A_{n}^{-m}(\gamma^{2})S^{m(1)}_{n}\left(z,\gamma\right)=\frac{1}{2}{\mathrm{i} ^{m+n}}\gamma^{m}\frac{(n-m)!}{(n+m)!}z^{m}(1-z^{-2})^{\frac{1}{2}m}\*\int_{-1 }^{1}e^{-\mathrm{i}\gamma zt}(1-t^{2})^{\frac{1}{2}m}\mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left( t,\gamma^{2}\right)\mathrm{d}t.
For further relations see ( , §8.6) , ( ) , ( , §16.13) , ( ) , and ( , §3.1) .

Generalized spheroidal wave functions and Coulomb spheroidal functions are solutions of the differential equation \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}\left((1-z^{2})\frac{\mathrm{d}w}{\mathrm{d}z} \right)+{\left(\lambda+\alpha z+\gamma^{2}(1-z^{2})-\frac{\mu^{2}}{1-z^{2}} \right)w}=0, which reduces to (LABEL:eq:SW.DE.DE) if \alpha=0.
Equation (LABEL:eq:SW.GS.DE) appears in astrophysics and molecular physics.
For the theory and computation of solutions of (LABEL:eq:SW.GS.DE) see ( ) , ( ) , ( ) , and ( ) .

Another generalization is provided by the differential equation \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}\left((1-z^{2})\frac{\mathrm{d}w}{\mathrm{d}z} \right)+\left(\lambda+\gamma^{2}(1-z^{2})-\frac{\alpha(\alpha+1)}{z^{2}}-\frac {\mu^{2}}{1-z^{2}}\right)w=0, which also reduces to (LABEL:eq:SW.DE.DE) when \alpha=0.
See ( ) , ( ) with \mu=0 , and ( ) .

section.title: Wave Equation in Prolate Spheroidal Coordinates

para.sentence: Prolate spheroidal coordinates \xi,\eta,\phi are related to Cartesian coordinates x,y,z by x=c\sqrt{(\xi^{2}-1)(1-\eta^{2})}\cos\phi, y=c\sqrt{(\xi^{2}-1)(1-\eta^{2})}\sin\phi, z=c\xi\eta, where c is a positive constant.
(On the use of the symbol \theta in placeof \phi see §LABEL:sec:AL.FOT.la.)The
(x,y,z) -space without the z -axis corresponds to 1<\xi<\infty, -1<\eta<1, 0\leq\phi<2\pi.
The coordinate surfaces \xi=\mbox{const}.
are prolate ellipsoids of revolution with foci at x=y=0 , z=\pm c.
The coordinate surfaces \eta=\mbox{const}.
are sheets of two-sheeted hyperboloids of revolution with the same foci.
The focal line is given by \xi=1 , -1\leq\eta\leq 1 , and the rays \pm z\geq c , x=y=0 are given by \eta=\pm 1 , \xi\geq 1.

h_{\xi}^{2}=\left(\frac{\partial x}{\partial\xi}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{ \partial y}{\partial\xi}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{\partial z}{\partial\xi}\right )^{2}=\frac{c^{2}(\xi^{2}-\eta^{2})}{\xi^{2}-1}, , h_{\eta}^{2}=\left(\frac{\partial x}{\partial\eta}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{ \partial y}{\partial\eta}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{\partial z}{\partial\eta} \right)^{2}=\frac{c^{2}(\xi^{2}-\eta^{2})}{1-\eta^{2}}, , h_{\phi}^{2}=\left(\frac{\partial x}{\partial\phi}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{ \partial y}{\partial\phi}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{\partial z}{\partial\phi} \right)^{2}=c^{2}(\xi^{2}-1)(1-\eta^{2}).

\nabla^{2}=\frac{1}{h_{\xi}h_{\eta}h_{\phi}}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial\xi} \left(\frac{h_{\eta}h_{\phi}}{h_{\xi}}\frac{\partial}{\partial\xi}\right)+ \frac{\partial}{\partial\eta}\left(\frac{h_{\xi}h_{\phi}}{h_{\eta}}\frac{ \partial}{\partial\eta}\right)+\frac{\partial}{\partial\phi}\left(\frac{h_{\xi }h_{\eta}}{h_{\phi}}\frac{\partial}{\partial\phi}\right)\right)=\frac{1}{c^{2} (\xi^{2}-\eta^{2})}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial\xi}\left((\xi^{2}-1)\frac{ \partial}{\partial\xi}\right)+\frac{\partial}{\partial\eta}\left((1-\eta^{2}) \frac{\partial}{\partial\eta}\right)+\frac{\xi^{2}-\eta^{2}}{(\xi^{2}-1)(1- \eta^{2})}\frac{{\partial}^{2}}{{\partial\phi}^{2}}\right).

The wave equation \nabla^{2}w+\kappa^{2}w=0, transformed to prolate spheroidal coordinates (\xi,\eta,\phi) , admits solutions w(\xi,\eta,\phi)=w_{1}(\xi)w_{2}(\eta)w_{3}(\phi), where w_{1} , w_{2} , w_{3} satisfy the differential equations \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}\xi}\left((1-\xi^{2})\frac{\mathrm{d}w_{1}}{ \mathrm{d}\xi}\right)+\left(\lambda+\gamma^{2}(1-\xi^{2})-\frac{\mu^{2}}{1-\xi ^{2}}\right)w_{1}=0, \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}\eta}\left((1-\eta^{2})\frac{\mathrm{d}w_{2}}{ \mathrm{d}\eta}\right)+\left(\lambda+\gamma^{2}(1-\eta^{2})-\frac{\mu^{2}}{1- \eta^{2}}\right)w_{2}=0, \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w_{3}}{{\mathrm{d}\phi}^{2}}+\mu^{2}w_{3}=0, with \gamma^{2}=\kappa^{2}c^{2}\geq 0 and separation constants \lambda and \mu^{2}.
Equations (LABEL:eq:SW.PR.DE1) and (LABEL:eq:SW.PR.DE2) agree with (LABEL:eq:SW.DE.DE).

In most applications the solution w has to be a single-valued function of (x,y,z) , which requires \mu=m (a nonnegative integer) and w_{3}(\phi)=a_{3}\cos\left(m\phi\right)+b_{3}\sin\left(m\phi\right).
Moreover, w has to be bounded along the z -axis away from the focal line: this requires w_{2}(\eta) to be bounded when -1<\eta<1.

Then \lambda=\lambda^{m}_{n}\left(\gamma^{2}\right) for some n=m,m+1,m+2,\dots , and the general solution of (LABEL:eq:SW.PR.DE2) is w_{2}(\eta)=a_{2}\mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(\eta,\gamma^{2}\right)+b_{2}\mathsf{ Qs}^{m}_{n}\left(\eta,\gamma^{2}\right).
The solution of (LABEL:eq:SW.PR.DE1) with \mu=m is w_{1}(\xi)=a_{1}S^{m(1)}_{n}\left(\xi,\gamma\right)+b_{1}S^{m(2)}_{n}\left(\xi ,\gamma\right).
If b_{1}=b_{2}=0 , then the function (LABEL:eq:SW.PR.SO) is a twice-continuously differentiable solutionof (LABEL:eq:SW.PR.SW) in the entire (x,y,z) -space.
If b_{2}=0 , then this property holds outside the focal line.

subsection.title: The Interior Dirichlet Problem for Prolate Ellipsoids

para.sentence: Equation (LABEL:eq:SW.PR.SW) for \xi\leq\xi_{0} , and subject to the boundary condition w=0 on the ellipsoid given by \xi=\xi_{0} , poses an eigenvalue problem with \kappa^{2} as spectral parameter.
The eigenvalues are given by c^{2}\kappa^{2}=\gamma^{2} , where \gamma is determined from the condition S^{m(1)}_{n}\left(\xi_{0},\gamma\right)=0.
The corresponding eigenfunctions are given by (LABEL:eq:SW.PR.SO), (LABEL:eq:SW.PR.U1), (LABEL:eq:SW.PR.U2), (LABEL:eq:SW.PR.U3), with b_{1}=b_{2}=0.

For the Dirichlet boundary-value problem of the region \xi_{1}\leq\xi\leq\xi_{2} between two ellipsoids, the eigenvalues aredetermined from w_{1}(\xi_{1})=w_{1}(\xi_{2})=0, with w_{1} as in (LABEL:eq:SW.PR.U1).
The corresponding eigenfunctions are given as before with b_{2}=0.
For further applications see ( ) , ( ) and the references cited therein; also ( ) , ( ) , and ( ) .

section.title: Wave Equation in Oblate Spheroidal Coordinates

para.sentence: Oblate spheroidal coordinates \xi,\eta,\phi are related to Cartesian coordinates x,y,z by x=c\sqrt{(\xi^{2}+1)(1-\eta^{2})}\cos\phi, y=c\sqrt{(\xi^{2}+1)(1-\eta^{2})}\sin\phi, z=c\xi\eta, where c is a positive constant.
(On the use of the symbol \theta in place of \phi see §LABEL:sec:AL.FOT.la.)The
(x,y,z) -space without the z -axis and the disk z=0 , x^{2}+y^{2}\leq c^{2} corresponds to 0<\xi<\infty, -1<\eta<1, 0\leq\phi<2\pi.
The coordinate surfaces \xi=\mbox{const}.
are oblate ellipsoids of revolution with focal circle z=0 , x^{2}+y^{2}=c^{2}.
The coordinate surfaces \eta=\mbox{const}.
are halves of one-sheeted hyperboloids of revolution with the same focal circle.
The disk z=0 , x^{2}+y^{2}\leq c^{2} is given by \xi=0 , -1\leq\eta\leq 1 , and the rays \pm z\geq 0 , x=y=0 are given by \eta=\pm 1 , \xi\geq 0.

\nabla^{2}=\frac{1}{c^{2}(\xi^{2}+\eta^{2})}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial\xi} \left((\xi^{2}+1)\frac{\partial}{\partial\xi}\right)+\frac{\partial}{\partial \eta}\left((1-\eta^{2})\frac{\partial}{\partial\eta}\right)+\frac{\xi^{2}+\eta ^{2}}{(\xi^{2}+1)(1-\eta^{2})}\frac{{\partial}^{2}}{{\partial\phi}^{2}}\right).

The wave equation (LABEL:eq:SW.PR.SW), transformed to oblate spheroidal coordinates (\xi,\eta,\phi) , admits solutions of the form (LABEL:eq:SW.PR.SO), where w_{1} satisfies the differential equation \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}\xi}\left((1+\xi^{2})\frac{\mathrm{d}w_{1}}{ \mathrm{d}\xi}\right)-\left(\lambda+\gamma^{2}(1+\xi^{2})-\frac{\mu^{2}}{1+\xi ^{2}}\right)w_{1}=0, and w_{2} , w_{3} satisfy (LABEL:eq:SW.PR.DE2) and (LABEL:eq:SW.PR.DE3), respectively, with \gamma^{2}=-\kappa^{2}c^{2}\leq 0 and separation constants \lambda and \mu^{2}.
Equation (LABEL:eq:SW.OB.DE1) can be transformed to equation (LABEL:eq:SW.DE.DE) by the substitution z=\pm i\xi.
In most applications the solution w has to be a single-valued function of (x,y,z) , which requires \mu=m (a nonnegative integer).
Moreover, the solution w has to be bounded along the z -axis: this requires w_{2}(\eta) to be bounded when -1<\eta<1.
Then \lambda=\lambda^{m}_{n}\left(\gamma^{2}\right) for some n=m,m+1,m+2,\dots , and the solution of (LABEL:eq:SW.PR.DE2) is given by (LABEL:eq:SW.PR.U2).
The solution of (LABEL:eq:SW.OB.DE1) is given by w_{1}(\xi)=a_{1}S^{m(1)}_{n}\left(i\xi,\gamma\right)+b_{1}S^{m(2)}_{n}\left(i \xi,\gamma\right).
If b_{1}=b_{2}=0 , then the function (LABEL:eq:SW.PR.SO) is a twice-continuously differentiable solution of (LABEL:eq:SW.PR.SW) in the entire (x,y,z) -space.
If b_{2}=0 , then this property holds outside the focal disk.

subsection.title: The Interior Dirichlet Problem for Oblate Ellipsoids

para.sentence: Equation (LABEL:eq:SW.PR.SW) for \xi\leq\xi_{0} together with the boundarycondition w=0 on the ellipsoid given by \xi=\xi_{0} , poses an eigenvalue problem with \kappa^{2} as spectral parameter.
The eigenvalues are given by c^{2}\kappa^{2}=-\gamma^{2} , where \gamma^{2} is determined from the condition S^{m(1)}_{n}\left(\mathrm{i}\xi_{0},\gamma\right)=0.
The corresponding eigenfunctions are then given by (LABEL:eq:SW.PR.SO), (LABEL:eq:SW.OB.U1), (LABEL:eq:SW.PR.U2), (LABEL:eq:SW.PR.U3), with b_{1}=b_{2}=0.
For further applications see ( ) , ( ) and the references cited therein; also ( ) and ( ) .
Let \tau (>0) and \sigma (>0) be given.

Set \gamma=\tau\sigma and define \phi_{n}(t)=\sqrt{\frac{2n+1}{2\tau}}\sqrt{\Lambda_{n}}\mathsf{Ps}^{0}_{n} \left(\frac{t}{\tau},\gamma^{2}\right), subject to n=0,1,2,\dots, \Lambda_{n}=\frac{2\gamma}{\pi}\left(K_{n}^{0}(\gamma)A_{n}^{0}(\gamma^{2}) \right)^{2}; see §LABEL:sec:SW.SJ.CC.
\int_{-\tau}^{\tau}\frac{\sin\sigma(t-s)}{\pi(t-s)}\phi_{n}(s)\mathrm{d}s= \Lambda_{n}\phi_{n}(t).

\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}e^{-\mathrm{i}t\omega}\phi_{n}(t)\mathrm{d}t=(-\mathrm{ i})^{n}\sqrt{\frac{2\pi\tau}{\sigma\Lambda_{n}}}\phi_{n}\left(\frac{\tau}{ \sigma}\omega\right)\chi_{\sigma}(\omega), \int_{-\tau}^{\tau}e^{-\mathrm{i}t\omega}\phi_{n}(t)\mathrm{d}t=(-\mathrm{i})^ {n}\sqrt{\frac{2\pi\tau\Lambda_{n}}{\sigma}}\phi_{n}\left(\frac{\tau}{\sigma} \omega\right), where \chi_{\sigma}(\omega)=\begin{cases}1,&\mbox{$|\omega|\leq\sigma$},\\ 0,&\mbox{$|\omega|>\sigma$}.\end{cases } Equations (LABEL:eq:SW.SI.F1) and (LABEL:eq:SW.SI.F4) show that the functions \phi_{n} are \sigma -bandlimited, that is, their Fourier transform vanishes outside the interval [-\sigma,\sigma].
\int_{-\tau}^{\tau}\phi_{k}(t)\phi_{n}(t)\mathrm{d}t=\Lambda_{n}\delta_{k,n}, , \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\phi_{k}(t)\phi_{n}(t)\mathrm{d}t=\delta_{k,n}.
The sequence \phi_{n} , n=0,1,2,\dots forms an orthonormal basis in the space of \sigma -bandlimited functions, and, after normalization, an orthonormal basis in L^{2}(-\tau,\tau).

The maximum (or least upper bound) \mathrm{B} of all numbers \beta=\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{-\sigma}^{\sigma}\left|\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}e^{- \mathrm{i}t\omega}f(t)\mathrm{d}t\right|^{2}\mathrm{d}\omega taken over all f\in L^{2}(-\infty,\infty) subject to \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}|f(t)|^{2}\mathrm{d}t=1, \int_{-\tau}^{\tau}|f(t)|^{2}\mathrm{d}t=\alpha, for (fixed) \Lambda_{0}<\alpha\leq 1 , is given by \operatorname{arccos}\sqrt{\mathrm{B}}+\operatorname{arccos}\sqrt{\alpha}= \operatorname{arccos}\sqrt{\Lambda_{0}}, or equivalently, \mathrm{B}=\left(\sqrt{\Lambda_{0}\alpha}+\sqrt{1-\Lambda_{0}}\sqrt{1-\alpha} \right)^{2}.
The corresponding function f is given by f(t)=a\phi_{0}(t)\chi_{\tau}(t)+b\phi_{0}(t)(1-\chi_{\tau}(t)), a=\sqrt{\frac{\alpha}{\Lambda_{0}}}, b=\sqrt{\frac{1-\alpha}{1-\Lambda_{0}}}.
If 0<\alpha\leq\Lambda_{0} , then \mathrm{B}=1.
For further information see ( ) , ( ) , ( , Chapter 6) , ( ) , and ( ) .
For small |\gamma^{2}| we can use the power-series expansion (LABEL:eq:SW.EV.EQ1).
( ) gives corresponding error bounds.

If |\gamma^{2}| is large we can use the asymptotic expansions in §LABEL:sec:SW.AE. Approximations to eigenvalues can be improved by using the continued-fraction equations from §LABEL:sec:SW.EV.TR and §LABEL:sec:SW.LF; see ( ) and ( , §3.93) .
Another method is as follows.
Let n-m be even.

For d sufficiently large, construct the d\times d tridiagonal matrix \mathbf{A}=[A_{j,k}] with nonzero elements A_{j,j}=(m+2j-2)(m+2j-1)-2\gamma^{2}\frac{(m+2j-2)(m+2j-1)-1+m^{2}}{(2m+4j-5)( 2m+4j-1)}, A_{j,j+1}=-\gamma^{2}\frac{(2m+2j-1)(2m+2j)}{(2m+4j-1)(2m+4j+1)}, A_{j,j-1}=-\gamma^{2}\frac{(2j-3)(2j-2)}{(2m+4j-7)(2m+4j-5)}, and real eigenvalues \alpha_{1,d} , \alpha_{2,d} , \dots , \alpha_{d,d} ,arranged in ascending order of magnitude.
Then \alpha_{j,d+1}\leq\alpha_{j,d}, and \lambda^{m}_{n}\left(\gamma^{2}\right)=\lim_{d\to\infty}\alpha_{p,d}, subject to p=\left\lfloor\frac{1}{2}(n-m)\right\rfloor+1.
The eigenvalues of \mathbf{A} can be computed by methods indicated in §§LABEL:sec:NM.LIN.LANCZS, LABEL:sec:NM.LIN.CEV.
The error satisfies \alpha_{p,d}-\lambda^{m}_{n}\left(\gamma^{2}\right)=O\left(\frac{\gamma^{4d}}{ 4^{2d+1}((m+2d-1)!(m+2d+1)!)^{2}}\right), subject to d\to\infty.

subsection.title: Spheroidal Wave Functions of the First Kind

para.sentence: If |\gamma^{2}| is large, then we can use the asymptotic expansions referred to in §LABEL:sec:SW.AE to approximate \mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(x,\gamma^{2}\right).

If \lambda^{m}_{n}\left(\gamma^{2}\right) is known, then we can compute \mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(x,\gamma^{2}\right) (not normalized) by solving the differential equation (LABEL:eq:SW.DE.DE) numerically with initial conditions w(0)=1 , w^{\prime}(0)=0 if n-m is even, or w(0)=0 , w^{\prime}(0)=1 if n-m is odd.
If \lambda^{m}_{n}\left(\gamma^{2}\right) is known, then \mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(x,\gamma^{2}\right) can be found by summing (LABEL:eq:SW.LF.EX).
The coefficients a^{m}_{n,r}(\gamma^{2}) are computed as the recessive solution of (LABEL:eq:SW.LF.REC2) (§LABEL:sec:NM.LDE), and normalized via (LABEL:eq:SW.LF.NO).
A fourth method, based on the expansion (LABEL:eq:SW.LF.EX), is as follows.
Let \mathbf{A} be the d\times d matrix given by (LABEL:eq:SW.MC.T1) if n-m is even, or by (LABEL:eq:SW.MC.T5) if n-m is odd.

Form the eigenvector [e_{1,d},e_{2,d},\dots,e_{d,d}]^{\mathrm{T}} of \mathbf{A} associated with the eigenvalue \alpha_{p,d} , p=\left\lfloor\frac{1}{2}(n-m)\right\rfloor+1 , normalized according to \sum_{j=1}^{d}e_{j,d}^{2}\frac{(n+m+2j-2p)!}{(n-m+2j-2p)!}\frac{1}{2n+4j-4p+1} =\frac{(n+m)!}{(n-m)!}\frac{1}{2n+1}.
Then a_{n,k}^{m}(\gamma^{2})=\lim_{d\to\infty}e_{k+p,d}, \mathsf{Ps}^{m}_{n}\left(x,\gamma^{2}\right)=\lim_{d\to\infty}\sum_{j=1}^{d}(- 1)^{j-p}e_{j,d}\mathsf{P}^{m}_{n+2(j-p)}\left(x\right).
For error estimates see ( ) .

The coefficients a_{n,k}^{m}(\gamma^{2}) calculated in §LABEL:sec:SW.MC.CW can be used to compute S^{m(j)}_{n}\left(z,\gamma\right) , j=1,2,3,4 from (LABEL:eq:SW.SJ.DF) as well as the connection coefficients K_{n}^{m}(\gamma) from (LABEL:eq:SW.SJ.KE) and (LABEL:eq:SW.SJ.KO).
For other methods see ( ) .
